For release Tuesday, Jan. 2
Help Wanted Index Falls, Shows Weakening Labor Market
DOC.TEXT: A widely watched measure of the labor market sent out weak signals in November, a business research group reported Monday. The Conference Board said the Help-Wanted Index dropped six points in November, erasing almost all of October's five-point gain. The seasonally adjusted index fell to 145 in November from October's 151 and September's 146. The November reading was 11 points lower than the year- earlier level. ``As the decade ends, the economy is not now growing fast enough to keep up with the rise in the working-age population,'' Conference Board economist Ken Goldstein said. ``Consequently, new entrants, or re-entrants, to the workforce spend a little more time finding jobs,'' he said. ``Clearly, this is a weakened labor market but not a declining one,'' he said, noting that the U.S. unemployment rate probably will edge up in 1990. The jobless rate was 5.4 percent in November, up from 5.3 percent in October and the same as in November of 1988. Goldstein said the rate may rise to 5.8 percent by June. Job advertising volume fell in seven of the nine regions of the country measured by the New York-based research group. Only the East South Central and Mountain regions showed increases while New England continued to be the weakest as it has been for several months. The Help-Wanted Index is based on ad volume in 51 major newspapers across the country. The Conference Board says ad volume has proven to be sensitive to labor market conditions and provides a gauge of change in the supply of jobs.
